newsitem.title: UK: Coffee--Futures rally hoists arabica differentials.
newsitem.headline: Coffee--Futures rally hoists arabica differentials.

text.p: A new rally in New York coffee futures on bullish U.S. stock data lifted washed arabica diffentials this week but robustas were softer on the weight of Far East sales.

The rally sent New York's May contract above the important $2.00 a lb mark for the second time this month. This sidelined many sellers although roaster demand remained strong into the second half of 1997.
"Roasters still have many price-fixations to be done especially against July," said one European trader.
The arabica futures were given a boost by news of a smaller-than-expected rise in U.S. March green coffee stocks.
Traders said the falling certified coffee stocks in New York, the possible squeeze on May and the coming strikes in Brazil and Colombia also added fuel to the U.S. rally.
But the negative point is the absence of fund interest and traders said this could be due to the dwindling open position in May.
The market's main concern was whether the planned truck drivers' strike in Colombia over a labour dispute would take place from Sunday and how long it would last.
The government had threatened to outlaw the stoppage but traders pointed out the last crippling strike in January was also illegal.
Colombia is expected to ship 600,000 to 700,000 70-kg bags of coffee in April and one trader said about half of this amount has yet to be shipped.
The port workers strike in Brazil would have little impact on coffee shipments as the strike was unlikely to last long.

In robustas, the cash differentials softened a bit this week as new crop coffee arrived at Indonesian ports although traders noted that the crop could be slightly smaller than the last season due to crop cycle.
But industry interest for robustas was quite limited and roasters were well-covered and were in no hurry to make additional purchases.
Vietnam is also in no rush to sell some 40,000 to 50,000 tonnes left until the next crop in October while Uganda exports have virtually come to a standstill with the crop coming to an end.
